neuropsychology.title: Neuropsychology
neuropsychology.description: Study brain structure, function, and plasticity in relation to behavior and cognition.
neuropsychology.author: PsychePedia Editorial Team

sections.title: Introduction to Neuropsychology
content: Neuropsychology is the study of brain-behavior relationships, examining how brain structure and function influence cognition, emotion, and behavior. This field bridges neuroscience and psychology to understand both normal functioning and the effects of brain damage or dysfunction. Clinical neuropsychologists assess and treat individuals with brain injuries, neurological diseases, and developmental disorders.

sections.title: Organization of the Nervous System
content:
**Central Nervous System (CNS)**: Brain and spinal cord
**Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)**: Nerves outside the CNS
**Major Brain Structures**:

**Cerebral Cortex**: The outer layer responsible for higher cognitive functions
- **Frontal Lobe**: Executive functions, planning, decision-making, motor control, personality
- **Parietal Lobe**: Sensory integration, spatial awareness, attention
- **Temporal Lobe**: Auditory processing, language comprehension, memory
- **Occipital Lobe**: Visual processing

**Subcortical Structures**:
- **Limbic System**: Emotion and memory (hippocampus, amygdala, cingulate gyrus)
- **Basal Ganglia**: Movement initiation and control
- **Thalamus**: Sensory relay station
- **Hypothalamus**: Homeostasis, hormone regulation

**Brainstem**: Vital functions (breathing, heart rate, sleep-wake cycles)
**Cerebellum**: Motor coordination, balance, motor learning

sections.title: Neural Communication
content:
**The Neuron**: Fundamental unit of the nervous system
- **Cell Body (Soma)**: Contains nucleus and metabolic machinery
- **Dendrites**: Receive signals from other neurons
- **Axon**: Transmits signals to other neurons
- **Axon Terminals**: Release neurotransmitters
- **Myelin Sheath**: Insulation that speeds signal transmission

**Action Potential**: Electrochemical signal traveling along the axon
- Resting potential: -70mV
- Depolarization: Sodium influx
- Repolarization: Potassium efflux
- Refractory period: Brief unresponsive period

**Synaptic Transmission**:
1. Action potential reaches axon terminal
2. Calcium influx triggers vesicle release
3. Neurotransmitters released into synaptic cleft
4. Binding to postsynaptic receptors
5. Excitatory (EPSP) or inhibitory (IPSP) effects
6. Neurotransmitter removal (reuptake, enzymatic degradation, diffusion)

**Major Neurotransmitter Systems**:
- **Glutamate**: Primary excitatory neurotransmitter
- **GABA**: Primary inhibitory neurotransmitter
- **Dopamine**: Reward, motivation, motor control
- **Serotonin**: Mood, sleep, appetite
- **Norepinephrine**: Arousal, attention
- **Acetylcholine**: Memory, muscle activation

sections.title: Neuroplasticity
content: **Neuroplasticity** refers to the brain's ability to change and reorganize throughout life.

**Types of Plasticity**:
- **Synaptic Plasticity**: Changes in synaptic strength (long-term potentiation, long-term depression)
- **Structural Plasticity**: Changes in dendritic spines, axonal sprouting
- **Neurogenesis**: Formation of new neurons (hippocampus, olfactory bulb)
- **Cortical Reorganization**: Remapping of cortical areas after injury
**Hebbian Learning**: 'Neurons that fire together, wire together' - coincident activity strengthens connections.
**Critical Periods**: Windows of heightened plasticity during development (e.g., language acquisition, visual development).
**Experience-Dependent Plasticity**: Brain changes in response to learning and environmental enrichment.

**Recovery After Brain Injury**:
- Diaschisis resolution: Recovery of temporarily dysfunctional connected areas
- Compensation: Intact brain regions assume functions of damaged areas
- Rehabilitation: Training-induced plasticity to restore function

sections.title: Hemispheric Specialization
content: **Lateralization** refers to the tendency for certain functions to be predominantly processed by one hemisphere.

**Left Hemisphere** (typically):
- Language production and comprehension
- Analytical and sequential processing
- Mathematical calculation
- Right-hand motor control

**Right Hemisphere** (typically):
- Visuospatial processing
- Face recognition
- Emotional prosody
- Holistic/gestalt processing
- Left-hand motor control

**Split-Brain Research**: Studies of patients with severed corpus callosum (Sperry, Gazzaniga) demonstrated hemispheric specialization and the role of the corpus callosum in interhemispheric communication.

**Important Caveats**:
- Lateralization is relative, not absolute
- Both hemispheres work together in most tasks
- Individual variation exists (especially in left-handers)
- Pop psychology oversimplifies (e.g., 'left-brained' vs. 'right-brained' people)

sections.title: Neuropsychological Assessment
content: Clinical neuropsychological assessment evaluates cognitive functions through standardized testing.

**Domains Assessed**:
- **Attention**: Sustained, selective, divided attention
- **Memory**: Working memory, verbal/visual learning, delayed recall
- **Language**: Naming, fluency, comprehension, repetition
- **Visuospatial**: Construction, perception, spatial reasoning
- **Executive Functions**: Planning, inhibition, cognitive flexibility, problem-solving
- **Processing Speed**: Speed of cognitive operations
- **Motor Functions**: Fine motor speed and dexterity

**Common Assessment Instruments**:
- Wechsler scales (WAIS, WMS)
- Trail Making Test
- Wisconsin Card Sorting Test
- Rey Complex Figure
- Boston Naming Test
- Stroop Test
**Interpretation**: Compare performance to normative data, identify patterns of strengths and weaknesses, relate to known brain-behavior relationships.

sections.title: Major Neurological Conditions
content:
**Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)**:
- Caused by external force to the head
- Severity ranges from mild (concussion) to severe
- Common deficits: attention, memory, executive function, emotional regulation

**Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident)**:
- Ischemic (blocked blood vessel) or hemorrhagic (bleeding)
- Symptoms depend on location and extent
- Common syndromes: aphasia, neglect, hemianopia

**Neurodegenerative Diseases**:
- **Alzheimer's Disease**: Progressive memory loss, language difficulties, visuospatial impairment
- **Parkinson's Disease**: Motor symptoms (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia) plus cognitive changes
- **Huntington's Disease**: Movement disorder with psychiatric and cognitive symptoms
- **Multiple Sclerosis**: Demyelinating disease with variable cognitive effects
**Epilepsy**: Recurrent seizures; cognitive effects depend on seizure type and focus location.

sections.title: Neuroimaging Techniques
content:
**Structural Imaging**:
- **CT (Computed Tomography)**: X-ray based; detects acute hemorrhage, structural abnormalities
- **MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)**: Superior soft tissue contrast; detailed structural views
- **DTI (Diffusion Tensor Imaging)**: Visualizes white matter tracts

**Functional Imaging**:
- **fMRI (functional MRI)**: Measures blood oxygenation (BOLD signal) as proxy for neural activity
- **PET (Positron Emission Tomography)**: Measures metabolic activity using radioactive tracers
- **SPECT (Single Photon Emission CT)**: Blood flow imaging

**Electrophysiological Methods**:
- **EEG (Electroencephalography)**: Records electrical activity from scalp; excellent temporal resolution
- **MEG (Magnetoencephalography)**: Records magnetic fields; excellent temporal and spatial resolution
- **ERP (Event-Related Potentials)**: Brain responses time-locked to stimuli
**Emerging Techniques**: Near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), optogenetics

fullSections.title: Introduction to Neuropsychology
content: Neuropsychology is the scientific study of brain-behavior relationships, examining how the structure and function of the brain influence cognition, emotion, and behavior. This interdisciplinary field bridges neuroscience and psychology, drawing on knowledge from anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, and clinical medicine to understand both normal brain function and the consequences of brain damage or disease.

The field has two major branches: **experimental neuropsychology** (or cognitive neuroscience), which studies brain-behavior relationships in healthy individuals using neuroimaging and experimental paradigms, and **clinical neuropsychology**, which applies this knowledge to assess, diagnose, and treat individuals with brain dysfunction.
**Historical Foundations**:

The scientific study of brain-behavior relationships began in the 19th century with observations of patients with localized brain damage. **Paul Broca (1861)** described a patient who could understand language but could not speak—autopsy revealed damage to the left frontal lobe (now Broca's area). **Carl Wernicke (1874)** identified a region in the left temporal lobe critical for language comprehension (Wernicke's area).

These cases established the principle of **cerebral localization**—that specific brain regions are associated with specific functions. However, other researchers like **Karl Lashley** emphasized the brain's capacity for **equipotentiality** (distributed function) and **mass action** (overall amount of cortex matters for complex tasks).

Modern neuropsychology recognizes that both localization and distributed processing are important: specific regions are specialized for particular functions, but these regions work together in networks to produce complex behavior.
**Why Study Neuropsychology?**:

1. **Understanding normal cognition**: Studying brain-damaged patients reveals how cognitive processes are organized
2. **Clinical assessment**: Neuropsychological testing helps diagnose brain disorders and characterize deficits
3. **Treatment planning**: Understanding deficits guides rehabilitation and accommodation
4. **Forensic applications**: Neuropsychological evidence is used in legal proceedings
5. **Research**: Advances in neuroimaging allow study of brain function in healthy individuals

fullSections.title: Organization of the Nervous System
content: The nervous system is divided into two main parts: the **Central Nervous System (CNS)**, comprising the brain and spinal cord, and the **Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)**, comprising all nerves outside the CNS.
**Peripheral Nervous System**:

The PNS is further divided into:
- **Somatic Nervous System**: Controls voluntary movements and carries sensory information
- **Autonomic Nervous System**: Controls involuntary functions
  - **Sympathetic**: 'Fight or flight' responses
  - **Parasympathetic**: 'Rest and digest' functions
  - **Enteric**: Controls gastrointestinal system
**Brain Overview**:

The brain weighs approximately 1.4 kg (3 lbs) and contains approximately 86 billion neurons and an equal number of glial cells. It is protected by the skull, meninges (three membrane layers), and cerebrospinal fluid.

**Cerebral Cortex**: The outermost layer of the brain, the cortex is a thin (2-4 mm) sheet of neural tissue that is highly folded (gyri = ridges; sulci = grooves) to maximize surface area. The cortex contains approximately 16 billion neurons and is responsible for higher cognitive functions.
The cortex is divided into four lobes:

**Frontal Lobe** (anterior to central sulcus):
- **Primary Motor Cortex** (precentral gyrus): Controls voluntary movement; somatotopically organized
- **Premotor and Supplementary Motor Areas**: Movement planning and sequencing
- **Prefrontal Cortex**: Executive functions including:
  - **Dorsolateral PFC**: Working memory, planning, cognitive flexibility
  - **Orbitofrontal Cortex**: Decision-making, reward processing, social behavior
  - **Anterior Cingulate Cortex**: Error monitoring, conflict detection, motivation
- **Broca's Area** (left hemisphere): Speech production

**Parietal Lobe** (posterior to central sulcus):
- **Primary Somatosensory Cortex** (postcentral gyrus): Processes touch, pressure, temperature, pain
- **Posterior Parietal Cortex**: Spatial awareness, attention, sensory integration
- **Supramarginal and Angular Gyri**: Language, reading, arithmetic

**Temporal Lobe** (below lateral fissure):
- **Primary Auditory Cortex**: Processes sound
- **Wernicke's Area** (left hemisphere): Language comprehension
- **Fusiform Face Area**: Face recognition
- **Parahippocampal Region**: Memory encoding, spatial navigation
- **Temporal Pole**: Semantic knowledge, social cognition

**Occipital Lobe** (most posterior):
- **Primary Visual Cortex (V1)**: Initial cortical processing of visual information
- **Visual Association Areas (V2, V3, V4, V5/MT)**: Higher-order visual processing
  - **Ventral Stream** ('what' pathway): Object recognition
  - **Dorsal Stream** ('where/how' pathway): Spatial location, visually-guided action
**Subcortical Structures**:

**Limbic System** (emotion and memory):
- **Hippocampus**: Critical for forming new explicit memories; spatial navigation
- **Amygdala**: Processing emotional stimuli, especially fear; emotional memory
- **Cingulate Gyrus**: Emotion regulation, pain processing, decision-making
- **Mammillary Bodies**: Memory circuitry

**Basal Ganglia** (movement and learning):
- **Striatum** (caudate nucleus + putamen): Input structure; motor and cognitive functions
- **Globus Pallidus**: Output structure
- **Substantia Nigra**: Dopamine production; degeneration causes Parkinson's disease
- **Subthalamic Nucleus**: Movement regulation

**Diencephalon**:
- **Thalamus**: Relay station for sensory information (except smell) to cortex
- **Hypothalamus**: Homeostasis (hunger, thirst, temperature, circadian rhythms); hormone regulation via pituitary gland
- **Epithalamus**: Includes pineal gland (melatonin secretion)

**Brainstem** (vital functions):
- **Midbrain**: Eye movements, auditory reflexes, dopamine production (substantia nigra, VTA)
- **Pons**: Sleep, respiration, relays information to cerebellum
- **Medulla Oblongata**: Cardiovascular and respiratory control, reflexes (swallowing, coughing)
- **Reticular Formation**: Arousal, attention, sleep-wake regulation

**Cerebellum** ('little brain'):
- Contains more neurons than rest of brain combined
- Motor coordination, balance, motor learning
- Increasingly recognized role in cognition and emotion

fullSections.title: Neural Communication
content: The nervous system communicates through electrochemical signals. Understanding neural communication is fundamental to understanding how the brain produces behavior and how drugs and diseases affect brain function.
**The Neuron**:
Neurons are the fundamental information-processing units of the nervous system. While they vary in shape and size, most neurons share common features:

- **Cell Body (Soma)**: Contains the nucleus and metabolic machinery; integrates incoming signals
- **Dendrites**: Branch-like extensions that receive signals from other neurons; covered with dendritic spines that increase surface area for synapses
- **Axon**: Single long extension that transmits signals to other neurons; may be very long (up to 1 meter in spinal motor neurons)
- **Axon Hillock**: Where action potentials are initiated
- **Axon Terminals (Boutons)**: Endings that form synapses with other neurons; contain neurotransmitter vesicles
- **Myelin Sheath**: Fatty insulation produced by oligodendrocytes (CNS) or Schwann cells (PNS) that speeds signal transmission
- **Nodes of Ranvier**: Gaps in myelin where action potentials regenerate (saltatory conduction)

**Types of Neurons**:
- **Sensory (Afferent) Neurons**: Carry information from receptors to CNS
- **Motor (Efferent) Neurons**: Carry commands from CNS to muscles/glands
- **Interneurons**: Connect neurons within the CNS; most neurons are interneurons

**Glial Cells**: Non-neuronal cells that support neural function:
- **Astrocytes**: Structural support, blood-brain barrier, neurotransmitter regulation, metabolic support
- **Oligodendrocytes**: Produce myelin in CNS
- **Microglia**: Immune function, synaptic pruning
- **Schwann Cells**: Produce myelin in PNS
**The Action Potential**:
Neurons communicate via electrical signals called action potentials.

**Resting Potential** (-70 mV): At rest, the inside of the neuron is negatively charged relative to outside due to:
- Sodium-potassium pump (3 Na+ out, 2 K+ in)
- Selective permeability of membrane to K+
- Negatively charged proteins inside

**Action Potential Phases**:
1. **Stimulus**: Graded potential reaches threshold (-55 mV)
2. **Depolarization**: Voltage-gated Na+ channels open; Na+ rushes in; membrane potential rises to +30 mV
3. **Repolarization**: Na+ channels inactivate; K+ channels open; K+ flows out; membrane potential returns toward resting
4. **Hyperpolarization**: K+ channels slow to close; membrane potential briefly undershoots resting level
5. **Refractory Period**: Na+ channels recovering; neuron cannot fire another action potential (absolute refractory period) or requires stronger stimulus (relative refractory period)
**All-or-None Principle**: Action potentials occur at full strength or not at all; intensity is coded by firing rate, not amplitude.
**Saltatory Conduction**: In myelinated axons, action potentials 'jump' between nodes of Ranvier, dramatically increasing conduction speed (up to 150 m/s vs. 1 m/s in unmyelinated fibers).
**Synaptic Transmission**:
Neurons communicate at synapses through chemical (most common) or electrical transmission.

**Chemical Synapse Steps**:
1. Action potential arrives at axon terminal
2. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels open; Ca2+ enters terminal
3. Ca2+ triggers vesicle fusion with presynaptic membrane
4. Neurotransmitters released into synaptic cleft (exocytosis)
5. Neurotransmitters bind to postsynaptic receptors
6. Ion channels open or second messenger cascades activated
7. Postsynaptic potential generated (EPSP or IPSP)
8. Neurotransmitter cleared by reuptake, enzymatic degradation, or diffusion

**Postsynaptic Potentials**:
- **EPSP (Excitatory)**: Depolarization; moves membrane potential toward threshold
- **IPSP (Inhibitory)**: Hyperpolarization; moves membrane potential away from threshold

**Integration**: Postsynaptic neuron integrates thousands of EPSPs and IPSPs through:
- **Temporal Summation**: Adding signals that arrive close in time
- **Spatial Summation**: Adding signals from multiple synapses
**Major Neurotransmitter Systems**:

**Amino Acids**:
- **Glutamate**: Primary excitatory neurotransmitter; critical for learning and memory (NMDA, AMPA receptors); excess causes excitotoxicity
- **GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid)**: Primary inhibitory neurotransmitter; target of benzodiazepines and alcohol
- **Glycine**: Inhibitory; primarily in spinal cord and brainstem

**Monoamines**:
- **Dopamine**: Reward, motivation, motor control; implicated in schizophrenia, Parkinson's, addiction
- **Norepinephrine**: Arousal, attention, stress response
- **Serotonin**: Mood, sleep, appetite; target of many antidepressants
- **Histamine**: Arousal, allergic responses
**Acetylcholine**: Memory, attention, muscle activation; degeneration in Alzheimer's disease
**Neuropeptides**: Endorphins (pain modulation), substance P (pain), neuropeptide Y (appetite), oxytocin (social bonding), vasopressin (water balance, social behavior)

**Receptor Types**:
- **Ionotropic (Ligand-gated ion channels)**: Fast, direct effect (AMPA, NMDA, GABA-A, nicotinic ACh)
- **Metabotropic (G-protein coupled)**: Slower, indirect effect via second messengers; can have longer-lasting effects (mGluRs, GABA-B, muscarinic ACh, dopamine, serotonin)

fullSections.title: Neuroplasticity
content: **Neuroplasticity** refers to the brain's ability to change its structure and function in response to experience, learning, or injury. Once thought to be fixed after development, we now know the brain remains plastic throughout life, though plasticity decreases with age.
**Historical Context**:

The concept of brain plasticity was revolutionary. **Santiago Ramón y Cajal**, who won the Nobel Prize for describing neuron structure, initially believed the adult brain was fixed. However, he later speculated that learning might involve changes in connections between neurons.

**Donald Hebb (1949)** proposed the influential learning rule: 'When an axon of cell A is near enough to excite a cell B and repeatedly or persistently takes part in firing it, some growth process or metabolic change takes place in one or both cells such that A's efficiency, as one of the cells firing B, is increased.' This is summarized as 'neurons that fire together, wire together.'
**Types of Plasticity**:
**Synaptic Plasticity**: Changes in the strength of existing synaptic connections.

**Long-Term Potentiation (LTP)**: A lasting increase in synaptic strength following high-frequency stimulation. First demonstrated in the hippocampus by Bliss and Lømo (1973).
- **Induction**: High-frequency stimulation activates NMDA receptors, allowing Ca2+ entry
- **Expression**: AMPA receptors inserted into postsynaptic membrane; increased neurotransmitter release
- **Maintenance**: Structural changes; protein synthesis required for late-phase LTP
- **Significance**: Considered a cellular basis for learning and memory

**Long-Term Depression (LTD)**: A lasting decrease in synaptic strength following low-frequency stimulation. Important for:
- Preventing saturation of potentiation
- Forgetting and clearing old information
- Fine-tuning synaptic weights
- Motor learning in cerebellum
**Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity (STDP)**: The precise timing between pre- and postsynaptic activity determines whether potentiation or depression occurs.
**Structural Plasticity**: Physical changes in neural structure.

**Dendritic Spine Dynamics**: Spines are small protrusions on dendrites where most excitatory synapses occur. They can:
- Form rapidly (minutes to hours) in response to learning
- Grow larger with strengthened connections
- Shrink or disappear with weakened connections
- Stabilize with repeated activation
**Axonal Sprouting**: Growth of new axon terminals to form new synapses. Occurs after injury (potentially adaptive or maladaptive) and in learning.

**Neurogenesis**: Formation of new neurons from neural stem cells.
- Confirmed in two regions in adult humans:
  - **Hippocampus (dentate gyrus)**: Important for memory; enhanced by exercise, enrichment; reduced by stress, aging
  - **Olfactory Bulb**: New neurons migrate from subventricular zone
- Extent and significance in adult humans remains debated
- Factors promoting neurogenesis: Exercise, learning, enriched environment, antidepressants
- Factors reducing neurogenesis: Stress, aging, inflammation, alcohol
**Cortical Map Reorganization**: The brain's topographic maps (e.g., somatosensory homunculus) can reorganize based on experience.

**Examples**:
- Musicians who play string instruments have enlarged cortical representation of left hand fingers
- London taxi drivers have larger posterior hippocampi (spatial navigation)
- After amputation, cortical area previously representing the limb may be 'taken over' by adjacent representations (can cause phantom limb sensations)
- Blind individuals show visual cortex activation during Braille reading
**Critical Periods and Sensitive Periods**:

**Critical Periods**: Time windows during development when specific experiences are required for normal development. If experience is absent, development is permanently altered.
- **Visual Development**: Monocular deprivation during critical period causes permanent amblyopia (lazy eye)
- **Language Acquisition**: First language must be acquired by puberty for full proficiency
- **Filial Imprinting**: Birds must be exposed to parent figure in first days of life

**Sensitive Periods**: Times of heightened plasticity when experience has greater impact, but change remains possible afterward (though more difficult).
- Second language learning
- Musical training
- Social development

**Mechanisms**: Critical periods are regulated by:
- Maturation of inhibitory circuits (GABA)
- Myelination (reduces plasticity)
- Perineuronal nets (extracellular matrix restricting plasticity)
- Neuromodulators (dopamine, norepinephrine, acetylcholine)
**Recovery After Brain Injury**:
**Diaschisis**: Temporary dysfunction in brain regions connected to damaged area, even if structurally intact. Recovery partly reflects resolution of diaschisis as connected regions recover function.
**Compensation**: Intact brain regions or neural circuits assume functions of damaged areas. Not true restoration but achieving goals through alternative means.

**Restoration**: True recovery of original function through:
- Regeneration (limited in adult mammalian CNS)
- Strengthening of partially damaged pathways
- Unmasking of latent pathways
- Recruitment of perilesional cortex

**Rehabilitation**: Intensive, task-specific training can promote plasticity and functional recovery.
- **Constraint-induced movement therapy**: Forcing use of affected limb promotes cortical reorganization
- **Cognitive rehabilitation**: Training exercises to improve attention, memory, executive function
- **Environmental enrichment**: Complex, stimulating environments promote recovery

**Factors Affecting Recovery**:
- Age (younger generally better)
- Lesion size and location
- Time since injury
- Rehabilitation intensity and timing
- Individual differences in plasticity
- Comorbidities (depression, substance use)

fullSections.title: Hemispheric Specialization
content: **Lateralization** refers to the tendency for certain cognitive functions to be predominantly processed by one cerebral hemisphere. While the two hemispheres appear superficially similar, they have structural and functional differences.
**Structural Asymmetries**:

- **Planum Temporale**: Larger on left in most people (related to language)
- **Sylvian Fissure**: Longer and more horizontal on left
- **Frontal Lobe**: Right extends further forward
- **Occipital Lobe**: Left extends further backward
- **Heschl's Gyrus**: More frequently doubled on right
**Functional Specialization**:

**Left Hemisphere** (in most right-handed individuals):
- **Language**: Production (Broca's area) and comprehension (Wernicke's area)
- **Analytical Processing**: Breaking down information into component parts
- **Sequential Processing**: Processing information in order
- **Verbal Memory**: Memory for words and verbal material
- **Mathematical Calculation**: Precise arithmetic
- **Motor Control**: Right side of body

**Right Hemisphere**:
- **Visuospatial Processing**: Mental rotation, spatial relationships, navigation
- **Face Recognition**: Fusiform face area more active on right
- **Emotional Prosody**: Understanding emotional tone of speech
- **Music Processing**: Especially pitch and melody
- **Holistic/Gestalt Processing**: Processing wholes rather than parts
- **Nonverbal Memory**: Memory for faces, spatial layouts, music
- **Motor Control**: Left side of body
**Split-Brain Research**:

The most dramatic demonstrations of hemispheric specialization came from studies of patients who underwent surgical severing of the corpus callosum (the major fiber bundle connecting the hemispheres) to treat severe epilepsy.
**Roger Sperry** and **Michael Gazzaniga** conducted landmark studies beginning in the 1960s. Key findings:

- **Disconnection**: Information presented to one hemisphere cannot be accessed by the other
- **Language Lateralization**: Left hemisphere can name objects; right cannot (in most patients)
- **Specialized Abilities**: Right hemisphere better at spatial tasks, face recognition; left better at analytical tasks
- **Unified Consciousness**: Despite disconnection, patients maintain sense of unified self

**Classic Demonstration**:
- Visual information presented to left visual field goes to right hemisphere only
- Right hemisphere cannot verbally report what it sees (lacks language)
- But can guide left hand to select the object
- Left hemisphere (speaking) confabulates explanations for actions initiated by right hemisphere
**The Interpreter**:

Gazzaniga proposed that the left hemisphere contains an 'interpreter' that creates explanations and narratives to make sense of behavior, even when the true causes are unknown. This has implications for understanding confabulation, self-knowledge, and consciousness.
**Contralateral Control**:

Each hemisphere primarily controls the opposite (contralateral) side of the body:
- Motor cortex in left hemisphere controls right limbs (and vice versa)
- Sensory information from right side processed in left hemisphere (and vice versa)
- Visual information from left visual field processed in right hemisphere (and vice versa)
**Important Caveats**:

**1. Relative, Not Absolute**: Lateralization is a matter of degree. Both hemispheres contribute to most functions. Language is the most lateralized function, yet the right hemisphere has significant language abilities.
**2. Both Hemispheres Work Together**: The corpus callosum contains approximately 200 million fibers enabling constant communication. In intact brains, hemispheres work as integrated systems.
**3. Individual Variation**: Approximately 95% of right-handers have left-hemisphere language dominance, but only about 70% of left-handers do. Some individuals have more bilateral representation.
**4. Plasticity**: If damage occurs early in life, functions can reorganize. Children who undergo left hemispherectomy can develop good language in the right hemisphere.

**5. Pop Psychology Oversimplifies**: There is no such thing as 'left-brained' or 'right-brained' people. Everyone uses both hemispheres. Personality traits, learning styles, and creativity are not determined by hemisphere dominance.
**6. Sex Differences**: Often overstated. Some studies suggest females have more bilateral language representation, but effect sizes are small and findings inconsistent.

fullSections.title: Neuropsychological Assessment
content: Clinical neuropsychological assessment is a comprehensive evaluation of cognitive, behavioral, and emotional functioning through standardized testing and clinical interview. It is used to characterize brain-behavior relationships, diagnose disorders, guide treatment, and document outcomes.
**Purposes of Neuropsychological Assessment**:

1. **Diagnosis**: Distinguishing between conditions (e.g., Alzheimer's vs. depression vs. normal aging)
2. **Characterizing Deficits**: Identifying specific cognitive strengths and weaknesses
3. **Localization**: Inferring which brain regions may be affected
4. **Treatment Planning**: Guiding rehabilitation, accommodations, return to work/school
5. **Tracking Change**: Monitoring progression or recovery over time
6. **Forensic Evaluation**: Assessing competency, disability, malingering
7. **Surgical Planning**: Pre-surgical evaluation for epilepsy surgery, tumor resection
8. **Research**: Characterizing cognitive profiles in research studies
**Components of Evaluation**:

**Clinical Interview**: Gathering history including:
- Presenting concerns and symptom timeline
- Medical history (especially neurological)
- Developmental history
- Educational and occupational history
- Psychiatric history
- Substance use
- Family history
- Current functioning and daily activities

**Behavioral Observations**: Noting:
- Effort and motivation
- Emotional state
- Response to failure
- Fatigue effects
- Sensory or motor difficulties
**Standardized Testing**: Systematic assessment of cognitive domains.
**Cognitive Domains Assessed**:

**Intellectual Functioning**:
- Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS-IV)
- Estimates premorbid functioning (WTAR, NAART)

**Attention and Concentration**:
- Digit Span (forward and backward)
- Continuous Performance Tests (CPT)
- Trail Making Test Part A
- Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT)
- Attention/concentration index from memory batteries

**Processing Speed**:
- WAIS Processing Speed Index (Coding, Symbol Search)
- Trail Making Test Part A
- Stroop Color Word Test (reading speed)

**Learning and Memory**:
- **Verbal Memory**: California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT), Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT), WMS Logical Memory
- **Visual Memory**: Rey Complex Figure (delayed recall), Brief Visuospatial Memory Test (BVMT), WMS Visual Reproduction
- **Working Memory**: Digit Span, Letter-Number Sequencing, Spatial Span

**Language**:
- **Naming**: Boston Naming Test
- **Fluency**: Letter fluency (FAS), Category fluency (animals)
- **Comprehension**: Token Test, BDAE subtests
- **Repetition**: BDAE Repetition subtests

**Visuospatial and Constructional Functions**:
- Rey Complex Figure (copy)
- Block Design (WAIS)
- Clock Drawing Test
- Judgment of Line Orientation
- Hooper Visual Organization Test

**Executive Functions**:
- **Cognitive Flexibility**: Trail Making Test Part B, Wisconsin Card Sorting Test
- **Inhibition**: Stroop Color-Word Test (interference), Go/No-Go tasks
- **Planning**: Tower of London, Tower of Hanoi
- **Abstract Reasoning**: WAIS Similarities, Matrix Reasoning
- **Judgment and Decision Making**: Iowa Gambling Task

**Motor Functions**:
- Finger Tapping Test
- Grooved Pegboard
- Grip Strength

**Emotional and Personality Functioning**:
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI)
- Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI)
- Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)
- Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI)

**Effort and Validity Testing**:
- Test of Memory Malingering (TOMM)
- Rey 15-Item Test
- Embedded validity indicators
- Performance validity tests (PVTs)
**Interpretation**:
Scores are compared to normative data (adjusted for age, sometimes education, gender, race/ethnicity).

**Score Classifications** (example using WAIS):
- 130+: Very Superior (2.2%)
- 120-129: Superior (6.7%)
- 110-119: High Average (16.1%)
- 90-109: Average (50%)
- 80-89: Low Average (16.1%)
- 70-79: Borderline (6.7%)
- <70: Extremely Low (2.2%)
**Pattern Analysis**: Neuropsychologists look for patterns of deficits that suggest particular syndromes or lesion locations.
**Ecological Validity**: Relating test findings to real-world functioning and daily activities.

fullSections.title: Major Neurological Conditions
content: Clinical neuropsychology addresses a wide range of conditions affecting the brain. Understanding these conditions' characteristic presentations helps with diagnosis and treatment planning.
**Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)**:
TBI results from external mechanical force to the head. It is a leading cause of death and disability, particularly in young adults.

**Classification by Severity**:
- **Mild TBI (Concussion)**: Brief or no loss of consciousness (<30 min), GCS 13-15, PTA <24 hours
- **Moderate TBI**: LOC 30 min-24 hours, GCS 9-12, PTA 1-7 days
- **Severe TBI**: LOC >24 hours, GCS 3-8, PTA >7 days

**Mechanisms**:
- **Primary Injury**: Direct damage at impact (contusions, lacerations, diffuse axonal injury)
- **Secondary Injury**: Cascade of cellular events (edema, ischemia, excitotoxicity, inflammation)

**Common Cognitive Deficits**:
- Attention and concentration difficulties
- Processing speed slowing
- Memory impairment (especially new learning)
- Executive dysfunction
- Language difficulties (less common)

**Common Behavioral/Emotional Changes**:
- Irritability and emotional lability
- Depression and anxiety
- Personality changes (especially with frontal injury)
- Impulsivity and disinhibition
- Fatigue
**Recovery**: Most recovery occurs in first 6-12 months; improvement may continue for years. Severe TBI often leaves permanent deficits.
**Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident)**:
Stroke occurs when blood supply to the brain is interrupted, causing cell death.

**Types**:
- **Ischemic Stroke** (87%): Blood vessel blockage (thrombotic or embolic)
- **Hemorrhagic Stroke** (13%): Blood vessel rupture (intracerebral or subarachnoid)
- **Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)**: Temporary blockage with symptoms resolving within 24 hours
**Classic Syndromes** (depend on vessel and location):

**Left Hemisphere Strokes**:
- **Broca's Aphasia**: Nonfluent speech, intact comprehension, frontal lesion
- **Wernicke's Aphasia**: Fluent but meaningless speech, poor comprehension, temporal lesion
- **Global Aphasia**: Severe deficits in all language functions, large lesion
- **Alexia/Agraphia**: Reading/writing impairments
- Right hemiparesis, right visual field cut

**Right Hemisphere Strokes**:
- **Hemispatial Neglect**: Failure to attend to left side of space (common with parietal lesions)
- **Anosognosia**: Lack of awareness of deficits
- Visuospatial and constructional deficits
- Prosopagnosia (face recognition impairment)
- Left hemiparesis, left visual field cut
**Neurodegenerative Diseases**:

**Alzheimer's Disease**:
- Most common cause of dementia (60-80% of cases)
- Progressive deterioration of memory, language, visuospatial abilities, executive function
- **Early Stage**: Memory impairment (especially episodic), word-finding difficulties, mild executive dysfunction
- **Middle Stage**: Increasing disorientation, behavioral changes, functional decline
- **Late Stage**: Severe cognitive impairment, motor symptoms, complete dependence
- **Neuropathology**: Amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, hippocampal atrophy

**Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)**:
- **Behavioral Variant**: Personality changes, disinhibition, apathy, executive dysfunction
- **Primary Progressive Aphasia**: Progressive language deterioration
  - Semantic variant: Loss of word meaning
  - Nonfluent variant: Effortful, agrammatic speech

**Parkinson's Disease**:
- **Motor Symptoms**: Tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, postural instability
- **Cognitive Changes**: Executive dysfunction, attention deficits, visuospatial impairment
- **Parkinson's Disease Dementia**: Develops in many patients over time
- **Dementia with Lewy Bodies**: Dementia with fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism

**Huntington's Disease**:
- Autosomal dominant genetic disorder (CAG repeat expansion)
- **Motor**: Chorea (involuntary movements), dystonia, motor impersistence
- **Cognitive**: Subcortical dementia (executive dysfunction, attention, processing speed)
- **Psychiatric**: Depression, irritability, apathy, psychosis

**Multiple Sclerosis**:
- Autoimmune demyelinating disease
- Variable course (relapsing-remitting, progressive)
- **Cognitive Deficits**: Processing speed, memory, executive function (in ~50% of patients)
- Pattern depends on lesion location
**Epilepsy**:
Recurrent unprovoked seizures. Cognitive effects depend on seizure type, frequency, focus location, medication, and surgery.

**Temporal Lobe Epilepsy** (most common focal epilepsy):
- Memory impairment (especially if hippocampus involved)
- Language deficits if left hemisphere focus
- Psychiatric comorbidity common

**Surgical Considerations**:
- Intracarotid sodium amobarbital (Wada) test to lateralize language/memory
- Neuropsychological testing pre- and post-surgery
- Risk of memory decline after temporal lobe resection

fullSections.title: Neuroimaging Techniques
content: Neuroimaging has revolutionized neuroscience and clinical practice by allowing visualization of brain structure and function in living individuals. Different techniques provide complementary information.
**Structural Imaging**:

**Computed Tomography (CT)**:
- Uses X-rays to create cross-sectional images
- **Advantages**: Fast, widely available, good for acute situations, shows bone well, detects acute hemorrhage
- **Disadvantages**: Radiation exposure, poor soft tissue contrast, limited for posterior fossa
- **Clinical Uses**: Emergency evaluation of head trauma, acute stroke, detecting tumors, hydrocephalus

**Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)**:
- Uses magnetic fields and radio waves; no ionizing radiation
- **Advantages**: Superior soft tissue contrast, multiple image types (T1, T2, FLAIR), high resolution
- **Disadvantages**: Longer scan time, claustrophobia issues, contraindicated with some implants, expensive
- **Clinical Uses**: Detecting tumors, MS lesions, hippocampal atrophy, cortical abnormalities, developmental malformations

**MRI Sequences**:
- **T1-weighted**: Good for anatomy; CSF dark, white matter bright
- **T2-weighted**: Good for pathology; CSF bright, lesions bright
- **FLAIR**: T2 with CSF suppression; good for periventricular lesions
- **DWI (Diffusion-Weighted Imaging)**: Sensitive to acute stroke (cytotoxic edema)

**Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI)**:
- Measures diffusion of water molecules along white matter tracts
- Provides measures of white matter integrity (fractional anisotropy, mean diffusivity)
- **Tractography**: Visualizes major fiber pathways (corpus callosum, arcuate fasciculus, corticospinal tract)
- **Applications**: TBI, MS, normal development, surgical planning

**Volumetric MRI**:
- Quantitative measurement of brain structure volumes
- **Applications**: Hippocampal volume in Alzheimer's, gray matter volume changes in schizophrenia, developmental studies
**Functional Imaging**:

**Functional MRI (fMRI)**:
- Measures Blood Oxygen Level Dependent (BOLD) signal as proxy for neural activity
- Active neurons use oxygen → blood flow increases → more oxygenated blood → BOLD signal change
- **Spatial Resolution**: ~2-3 mm
- **Temporal Resolution**: ~1-2 seconds (limited by hemodynamic response)

**fMRI Applications**:
- **Cognitive Neuroscience Research**: Mapping brain activation during tasks
- **Presurgical Mapping**: Locating language and motor areas
- **Resting-State fMRI**: Measuring spontaneous fluctuations to identify functional networks

**Limitations of fMRI**:
- Indirect measure (blood flow, not neural activity)
- Correlational (cannot establish causation)
- Temporal resolution limited
- Sensitivity to motion artifacts
- Expensive

**Positron Emission Tomography (PET)**:
- Uses radioactive tracers to measure metabolic activity or receptor binding
- **FDG-PET**: Glucose metabolism (active areas use more glucose)
- **Amyloid PET**: Detects amyloid plaques in Alzheimer's
- **Tau PET**: Detects neurofibrillary tangles
- **Receptor PET**: Measures neurotransmitter receptors (dopamine, serotonin)
- **Disadvantages**: Radiation exposure, expensive, lower resolution than MRI

**Single Photon Emission CT (SPECT)**:
- Similar to PET but uses different tracers
- Less expensive than PET
- Measures cerebral blood flow
- **Applications**: Dementia evaluation, epilepsy focus localization
**Electrophysiological Methods**:

**Electroencephalography (EEG)**:
- Records electrical activity from scalp electrodes
- **Advantages**: Excellent temporal resolution (milliseconds), inexpensive, portable
- **Disadvantages**: Poor spatial resolution, primarily measures cortical activity
- **Clinical Uses**: Epilepsy diagnosis, sleep studies, brain death determination

**EEG Rhythms**:
- Delta (0.5-4 Hz): Deep sleep, pathology when awake
- Theta (4-8 Hz): Drowsiness, memory encoding
- Alpha (8-12 Hz): Relaxed, eyes closed
- Beta (12-30 Hz): Active thinking, concentration
- Gamma (>30 Hz): Cognitive processing, binding

**Event-Related Potentials (ERPs)**:
- EEG responses time-locked to stimuli or events
- Averaging reveals components: P1, N1, P2, N2, P300, N400, etc.
- Each component reflects different cognitive processes
- **Applications**: Research on attention, perception, language, memory

**Magnetoencephalography (MEG)**:
- Measures magnetic fields produced by neural activity
- **Advantages**: Excellent temporal resolution, better spatial localization than EEG
- **Disadvantages**: Very expensive, requires magnetically shielded room
- **Applications**: Presurgical mapping, epilepsy, cognitive neuroscience
**Brain Stimulation Techniques**:

**Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)**:
- Magnetic pulses induce electrical currents in cortex
- **Single-pulse TMS**: Disrupts processing (virtual lesion)
- **Repetitive TMS (rTMS)**: Can have lasting effects; therapeutic applications in depression
- Establishes causal role of brain regions

**Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS)**:
- Weak electrical current applied to scalp
- Modulates cortical excitability
- Research and therapeutic applications

**Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)**:
- Surgical implantation of electrodes
- Used for Parkinson's disease, essential tremor, OCD, depression

sensation-perception.description: Explore how we detect, process, and interpret sensory information from the environment.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Sensation and perception are fundamental processes by which we experience and understand the world. **Sensation** refers to the detection of physical energy by sensory receptors, while **perception** is the organization, interpretation, and conscious experience of sensory information. Together, these processes transform physical stimuli into meaningful psychological experiences.

sections.title: Basic Principles of Sensation
content: **Transduction**: The conversion of physical energy into neural signals by specialized receptor cells.

**Sensory Thresholds**:
- **Absolute Threshold**: Minimum stimulus intensity detected 50% of the time
- **Difference Threshold (JND)**: Minimum difference between stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time
- **Weber's Law**: The JND is proportional to stimulus magnitude (ΔI/I = k)

**Signal Detection Theory**: Detection depends not only on stimulus intensity but also on:
- Sensitivity (ability to detect signals)
- Response bias (criterion for reporting detection)
- Hits, misses, false alarms, correct rejections
**Sensory Adaptation**: Decreased sensitivity to constant stimulation (e.g., adapting to room temperature).

sections.title: The Visual System
content:
**Eye Structure**:
- **Cornea**: Transparent outer covering; refracts light
- **Pupil/Iris**: Controls light entry
- **Lens**: Focuses light (accommodation)
- **Retina**: Contains photoreceptors

**Photoreceptors**:
- **Rods**: Sensitive to dim light; peripheral vision; no color
- **Cones**: Color vision; fine detail; concentrated in fovea

**Visual Pathway**:
1. Retina → Optic nerve
2. Optic chiasm (partial crossing)
3. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN) of thalamus
4. Primary Visual Cortex (V1) in occipital lobe
5. Higher visual areas (V2, V4, IT, etc.)

**Color Vision**:
- **Trichromatic Theory**: Three cone types (S, M, L wavelengths)
- **Opponent-Process Theory**: Color processed in opposing pairs (red-green, blue-yellow, black-white)
- Both theories are correct at different processing levels
**Depth Perception**: Binocular cues (retinal disparity, convergence) and monocular cues (relative size, interposition, linear perspective, texture gradient, motion parallax).

sections.title: The Auditory System
content:
**Sound Properties**:
- **Frequency (Hz)**: Perceived as pitch
- **Amplitude**: Perceived as loudness
- **Timbre**: Quality/complexity of sound

**Ear Structure**:
- **Outer Ear**: Pinna, ear canal (collects and funnels sound)
- **Middle Ear**: Eardrum, ossicles (amplify vibrations)
- **Inner Ear**: Cochlea (fluid-filled, contains hair cells)

**Theories of Pitch Perception**:
- **Place Theory**: Different frequencies stimulate different locations on basilar membrane (best for high frequencies)
- **Frequency Theory**: Rate of neural firing matches sound frequency (best for low frequencies)
- **Volley Principle**: Groups of neurons fire in volleys for intermediate frequencies
**Auditory Pathway**: Cochlea → Auditory nerve → Brainstem nuclei → Medial geniculate nucleus → Primary auditory cortex (temporal lobe)
**Sound Localization**: Interaural time differences and intensity differences.

sections.title: Other Sensory Systems
content:
**Somatosensory System** (touch, temperature, pain, proprioception):
- Multiple receptor types for different stimuli
- Pathway through spinal cord to somatosensory cortex
- Somatotopic organization (homunculus)

**Pain**:
- Fast pain (Aδ fibers): Sharp, localized
- Slow pain (C fibers): Dull, diffuse
- Gate Control Theory: Spinal cord 'gate' modulates pain signals
- Descending modulation from brain
**Chemical Senses**:

**Gustation (Taste)**:
- Five basic tastes: sweet, sour, salty, bitter, umami
- Taste receptors on tongue and oral cavity
- Pathway to gustatory cortex (insula)

**Olfaction (Smell)**:
- Olfactory receptors in nasal cavity
- Direct connection to olfactory bulb and limbic system
- Approximately 400 receptor types; combinatorial coding

sections.title: Perceptual Organization
content: **Gestalt Principles**: The whole is different from the sum of its parts

- **Figure-Ground**: Separating object from background
- **Proximity**: Elements close together grouped together
- **Similarity**: Similar elements grouped together
- **Continuity**: Preference for continuous, smooth patterns
- **Closure**: Tendency to complete incomplete figures
- **Common Fate**: Elements moving together grouped together

**Perceptual Constancies**:
- **Size Constancy**: Objects perceived as same size despite retinal image changes
- **Shape Constancy**: Objects perceived as same shape despite viewing angle changes
- **Color Constancy**: Colors perceived as stable despite lighting changes
**Visual Illusions**: Reveal assumptions built into perceptual processing (e.g., Müller-Lyer, Ponzo, Ames room).

sections.title: Top-Down and Bottom-Up Processing
content:
**Bottom-Up Processing** (data-driven):
- Analysis begins with sensory input
- Building from simple features to complex percepts
- Feature detection, edge detection

**Top-Down Processing** (concept-driven):
- Prior knowledge, expectations, context influence perception
- Schemas guide interpretation
- Perceptual set: Readiness to perceive in certain ways
**Integration**: Perception involves continuous interaction between bottom-up and top-down processes.

**Examples**:
- Reading ambiguous handwriting (context helps)
- Recognizing faces in random patterns (pareidolia)
- The 'cocktail party effect' (selective attention to meaningful stimuli)

sections.title: Attention and Perception
content:
**Selective Attention**: Focusing on specific stimuli while filtering others
- **Broadbent's Filter Theory**: Early selection based on physical features
- **Deutsch-Norman Late Selection**: Meaning processed before selection
- **Treisman's Attenuation Theory**: Unattended information weakened, not completely blocked
**Inattentional Blindness**: Failure to notice unexpected stimuli when attention is focused elsewhere (e.g., gorilla experiment).
**Change Blindness**: Failure to detect changes when brief disruption occurs.
**Binding Problem**: How the brain integrates features processed in different areas into unified percepts.
**Feature Integration Theory** (Treisman): Attention required to bind features into coherent objects.

fullSections.title: Introduction
content: Sensation and perception are the fundamental processes by which we experience and understand the world around us. These seemingly automatic processes involve an extraordinarily complex chain of events, from the physical energy impacting our sensory organs to the rich, meaningful experiences we have of objects, people, and events.

**Sensation** refers to the detection of physical energy (light, sound waves, chemical molecules, pressure, temperature) by specialized receptor cells in our sensory organs. This process transforms physical energy into neural signals—a process called **transduction**.

**Perception** is the organization, interpretation, and conscious experience of sensory information. Perception goes beyond mere detection to construct meaningful representations of the world. What we perceive is not a direct copy of physical reality but a construction based on sensory input, prior knowledge, expectations, and context.
**The Importance of Studying Sensation and Perception**:
1. **Understanding Reality**: Our entire knowledge of the external world comes through our senses. Understanding these processes reveals the nature and limits of human knowledge.

2. **Clinical Applications**: Many disorders affect sensory and perceptual processes (blindness, deafness, agnosia, hallucinations). Understanding normal function is essential for diagnosis and treatment.
3. **Technology and Design**: Knowledge of perception informs the design of displays, interfaces, virtual reality, and assistive devices.
4. **Understanding Consciousness**: Perception is one of the most tractable aspects of consciousness to study scientifically.
**Key Questions in the Field**:

- How is physical energy converted into neural signals?
- How does the brain construct percepts from neural activity?
- What is innate vs. learned in perception?
- How do perception and cognition interact?
- Why do illusions occur and what do they reveal about perceptual processing?
**Historical Perspectives**:

Philosophers have long debated perception. **Empiricists** (Locke, Berkeley, Hume) emphasized that perception derives from sensory experience. **Nativists** (Descartes, Kant) argued that some perceptual abilities are innate. Modern research confirms that both innate mechanisms and experience shape perception.

**The Gestalt psychologists** (Wertheimer, Koffka, Köhler) demonstrated that perception involves active organization—'the whole is different from the sum of its parts.' **J.J. Gibson** emphasized the richness of information available in the environment (ecological approach). **David Marr** and the computational approach asked what problems vision solves and how.

fullSections.title: Basic Principles of Sensation
content: Before examining specific sensory systems, we consider principles that apply across senses.
**Transduction**:
**Transduction** is the conversion of physical energy from the environment into neural signals. Each sensory system has specialized receptor cells adapted to detect specific forms of energy:

- **Photoreceptors** (vision): Respond to electromagnetic radiation (light)
- **Mechanoreceptors** (hearing, touch, vestibular): Respond to mechanical pressure or vibration
- **Chemoreceptors** (taste, smell): Respond to chemical molecules
- **Thermoreceptors**: Respond to temperature
- **Nociceptors**: Respond to potentially damaging stimuli (pain)

When physical energy stimulates a receptor, it causes changes in the receptor cell's membrane potential (receptor potential). If this potential reaches threshold, it triggers action potentials that travel to the brain.
**Sensory Coding**:
How do neural signals represent information about stimuli?

- **Temporal Coding**: Information encoded in the timing or rate of action potentials
- **Spatial Coding**: Information encoded in which neurons are active (labeled line principle)
- **Population Coding**: Information encoded in patterns of activity across many neurons
**Sensory Thresholds**:

**Absolute Threshold**: The minimum stimulus intensity that can be detected 50% of the time. Classic examples of absolute thresholds:
- Vision: Candle flame 30 miles away on a dark, clear night
- Hearing: Tick of a watch 20 feet away in a quiet room
- Taste: 1 teaspoon of sugar in 2 gallons of water
- Smell: 1 drop of perfume in 6-room apartment
- Touch: Wing of a bee falling on cheek from 1 cm
**Difference Threshold (Just Noticeable Difference, JND)**: The minimum difference between two stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time.
**Weber's Law**: The JND is a constant proportion of the stimulus magnitude:
ΔI/I = k (Weber fraction)
where ΔI is the JND, I is the stimulus intensity, and k is a constant that varies by sense.

**Weber Fractions**:
- Brightness: 1/60 (very sensitive to changes)
- Weight: 1/50
- Loudness: 1/10
- Taste (salt): 1/5
Weber's Law breaks down at very low and very high intensities.
**Fechner's Law**: Perceived intensity is proportional to the logarithm of physical intensity. This explains why we can perceive a huge range of physical intensities.
**Stevens' Power Law**: Perceived intensity is a power function of physical intensity. Different exponents for different senses (e.g., electric shock has high exponent, brightness has low exponent).
**Signal Detection Theory**:
Classic threshold theory assumed detection was simply determined by stimulus intensity. **Signal Detection Theory (SDT)** recognizes that detection is also influenced by:

**Sensitivity (d')**: Ability to discriminate signal from noise. Depends on:
- Signal strength
- Background noise
- Sensory system sensitivity

**Response Criterion (β or c)**: The amount of evidence required to report detection. Influenced by:
- Payoff matrix (consequences of hits, misses, false alarms, correct rejections)
- Expectations (base rate of signal occurrence)
- Instructions and motivation

**SDT Outcomes**:
- **Hit**: Signal present, reported present
- **Miss**: Signal present, reported absent
- **False Alarm**: Signal absent, reported present
- **Correct Rejection**: Signal absent, reported absent
SDT separates sensitivity from bias, providing a more complete account of detection. It has applications in medical diagnosis, quality control, and other fields.
**Sensory Adaptation**:
**Sensory adaptation** is the decreased sensitivity to constant or repeated stimulation. This is why you stop noticing the feel of your clothes or the hum of a refrigerator.

**Functions of Adaptation**:
- Increases sensitivity to change (which is often more important than absolute levels)
- Prevents sensory overload
- Conserves neural resources

**Examples**:
- Dark adaptation: Rods become more sensitive in darkness (takes ~30 minutes for full adaptation)
- Light adaptation: Cones adjust to bright light (faster, ~5 minutes)
- Temperature adaptation: Water feels less cold after you've been in it
- Olfactory adaptation: Odors become less noticeable over time
**Exception**: Pain adapts slowly or not at all—adaptive for survival.

fullSections.title: The Visual System
content: Vision is our dominant sense, with approximately half the cerebral cortex involved in visual processing. The visual system transforms patterns of light into rich perceptual experiences.
**Light and the Eye**:
**Light** is electromagnetic radiation in the visible spectrum (approximately 380-760 nm wavelength). The eye captures and focuses this light.
**Eye Structure**:

**Outer Protective Layer**:
- **Sclera**: Tough white outer covering
- **Cornea**: Transparent front portion; refracts (bends) light; provides most of the eye's focusing power

**Middle Layer (Uvea)**:
- **Iris**: Colored ring of muscle; controls pupil size
- **Pupil**: Opening that admits light; dilates in dim light, constricts in bright light
- **Ciliary Muscles**: Control lens shape for focusing
- **Choroid**: Blood supply to retina

**Inner Layer (Retina)**:
- Contains photoreceptors and neural circuitry
- Converts light to neural signals
**Lens**: Transparent structure behind iris; changes shape (accommodation) to focus on objects at different distances. Becomes less flexible with age (presbyopia).
**Vitreous Humor**: Clear gel filling the eye; maintains shape.
**Fovea**: Central region of retina with highest acuity; contains densely packed cones.
**Blind Spot (Optic Disc)**: Where optic nerve exits; no photoreceptors.
**The Retina**:
The retina is actually part of the brain, developmentally speaking. It contains several cell layers:
**Photoreceptors**:

**Rods** (~120 million):
- Sensitive to dim light (scotopic vision)
- Found throughout retina except fovea
- All rods contain rhodopsin (one type)
- Provide black-and-white vision
- Low acuity (many rods converge on each ganglion cell)
- Important for peripheral vision and night vision

**Cones** (~6 million):
- Require brighter light (photopic vision)
- Concentrated in fovea
- Three types: S (short/blue), M (medium/green), L (long/red)
- Provide color vision and fine detail
- High acuity in fovea (less convergence)

**Other Retinal Cells**:
- **Bipolar Cells**: Connect photoreceptors to ganglion cells
- **Ganglion Cells**: Axons form optic nerve; different types (midget, parasol, bistratified)
- **Horizontal Cells**: Lateral connections at photoreceptor level
- **Amacrine Cells**: Lateral connections at ganglion cell level

**Receptive Fields**: Ganglion cells respond to light in specific retinal areas. Many have **center-surround organization**: on-center cells are excited by light in the center and inhibited by light in the surround (or vice versa). This enhances edge detection.
**Visual Pathway**:

1. **Retina**: Light → photoreceptors → bipolar cells → ganglion cells
2. **Optic Nerve**: Ganglion cell axons exit eye
3. **Optic Chiasm**: Partial crossing—nasal fibers cross, temporal fibers do not. Result: left visual field projects to right hemisphere, and vice versa
4. **Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN)**: Thalamic relay station; maintains retinotopic organization; has six layers
5. **Primary Visual Cortex (V1/Striate Cortex)**: In occipital lobe; retinotopically organized; contains cells responsive to orientation, spatial frequency, etc.
6. **Extrastriate Visual Areas**: V2, V3, V4, V5/MT, etc.; increasingly complex processing
**Two Visual Streams** (Ungerleider & Mishkin; Milner & Goodale):

**Ventral Stream** ('What' pathway):
- V1 → V2 → V4 → Inferotemporal Cortex
- Object recognition, form, color
- Damage: Visual agnosia

**Dorsal Stream** ('Where/How' pathway):
- V1 → V2 → V5/MT → Posterior Parietal Cortex
- Spatial location, motion, visually-guided action
- Damage: Optic ataxia, akinetopsia
**Color Vision**:

**Trichromatic Theory** (Young-Helmholtz):
- Three types of cones with different spectral sensitivities
- Color perception based on relative activation of S, M, L cones
- Explains color matching and color blindness

**Color Blindness**:
- Protanopia: Missing L cones (red-blind)
- Deuteranopia: Missing M cones (green-blind)
- Tritanopia: Missing S cones (blue-blind, rare)
- More common in males (~8%) due to X-linked genes

**Opponent-Process Theory** (Hering):
- Color processed in opponent pairs: red-green, blue-yellow, black-white
- Explains afterimages, color contrast, impossibility of seeing 'reddish-green'
**Integration**: Trichromatic processing at receptor level; opponent processing at ganglion and higher levels.
**Depth Perception**:

**Binocular Cues** (require two eyes):
- **Retinal Disparity**: Different images on each retina; brain computes depth from disparity
- **Convergence**: Eyes turn inward for near objects; muscle feedback provides depth information

**Monocular Cues** (available with one eye):
- **Interposition/Occlusion**: Near objects block distant ones
- **Relative Size**: Smaller objects appear more distant
- **Linear Perspective**: Parallel lines converge in distance
- **Texture Gradient**: Texture becomes finer with distance
- **Atmospheric Perspective**: Distant objects appear hazier and bluer
- **Motion Parallax**: Near objects move faster across retina when head moves
- **Familiar Size**: Known object size provides distance information

fullSections.title: Perceptual Organization and Constancies
content: Perception involves organizing raw sensory input into meaningful representations. This organization is not entirely determined by the stimulus—the brain actively constructs percepts.
**Gestalt Principles**:

The **Gestalt psychologists** (early 20th century Germany) demonstrated that perception involves holistic organization. Their motto: 'The whole is different from (not greater than) the sum of its parts.'
**Principles of Perceptual Grouping**:

**Figure-Ground Segregation**: Perceiving objects as distinct from their backgrounds. The figure appears in front, has shape, and is more memorable. Ambiguous figure-ground relationships create bistable percepts (e.g., Rubin's vase/faces).
**Proximity**: Elements close together tend to be grouped together. The brain assumes nearby things belong together.
**Similarity**: Elements that are similar (in color, shape, size, orientation) tend to be grouped together.
**Continuity (Good Continuation)**: We prefer smooth, continuous contours over abrupt changes. Overlapping lines are perceived as continuous.
**Closure**: We tend to complete incomplete figures, perceiving a whole even when parts are missing.
**Common Fate**: Elements that move together tend to be grouped together. Important for perceiving objects in motion.
**Common Region**: Elements within the same bounded region tend to be grouped together.
**Connectedness**: Elements that are connected tend to be grouped together.
**Prägnanz (Good Form/Simplicity)**: We perceive the simplest, most stable organization possible.
**Modern Understanding**: Gestalt principles reflect statistical regularities in the natural world. The brain has evolved or learned that elements sharing these properties usually belong together.
**Perceptual Constancies**:
Despite dramatic changes in sensory input, we perceive objects as stable and constant. This stability is essential for recognizing objects across varying conditions.

**Size Constancy**: Objects are perceived as the same size despite changes in viewing distance (which changes retinal image size). The brain uses depth cues to scale perceived size. Failures of size constancy contribute to some illusions (e.g., Ames room, moon illusion).

**Shape Constancy**: Objects are perceived as the same shape despite changes in viewing angle (which changes retinal image shape). A circular plate seen from an angle projects an ellipse but is perceived as circular.

**Brightness/Lightness Constancy**: Surfaces are perceived as having constant lightness despite changes in illumination. A white paper in shadow is still perceived as white, not gray. The brain considers the overall illumination context.

**Color Constancy**: Colors are perceived as stable despite changes in the wavelength composition of illumination. A banana looks yellow under both incandescent and fluorescent lights, even though the wavelengths reaching the eye differ dramatically. The brain discounts the illumination based on context.

**Mechanisms of Constancy**:
- **Taking context into account**: Using surrounding information
- **Prior knowledge**: Understanding typical object properties
- **Perceptual computation**: Algorithms that recover stable properties from varying input
**Visual Illusions**:
Illusions reveal the assumptions and processes underlying normal perception. They are not failures of the visual system but byproducts of mechanisms that usually serve us well.
**Geometric Illusions**:

**Müller-Lyer Illusion**: Lines with outward-pointing arrows appear longer than lines with inward-pointing arrows. Possible explanations: misapplied size constancy, angles affect perceived line length.
**Ponzo Illusion**: Two identical lines appear different in size when placed in a converging lines context (like railroad tracks). Linear perspective cues trigger size constancy mechanisms.
**Ames Room**: A specially constructed room that appears rectangular but is actually trapezoidal. People at different positions appear to be dramatically different sizes.
**Motion Illusions**:
**Apparent Motion (Phi Phenomenon)**: Perception of movement from static stimuli presented in sequence (basis of movies).
**Motion Aftereffect (Waterfall Illusion)**: After viewing motion in one direction, stationary objects appear to move in the opposite direction. Caused by adaptation of direction-selective neurons.
**Brightness/Color Illusions**:
**Simultaneous Contrast**: A gray patch appears lighter on a dark background and darker on a light background.
**Checker Shadow Illusion (Adelson)**: Two squares that are objectively the same luminance appear very different due to shadow context.
**Ambiguous/Multistable Percepts**:
**Necker Cube**: A line drawing that alternates between two perceived orientations.
**Rubin's Vase**: Alternates between vase and two faces.
These demonstrate that the same stimulus can give rise to different percepts, and that perception involves active interpretation.

fullSections.title: Top-Down and Bottom-Up Processing
content: Perception results from the interplay of two types of processing that work simultaneously.
**Bottom-Up Processing (Data-Driven Processing)**:
Bottom-up processing builds percepts from sensory input, starting with simple features and constructing increasingly complex representations.

**Characteristics**:
- Begins with physical stimulus
- Proceeds from simple to complex
- Feature detection and analysis
- Automatic and fast
- Independent of expectations or prior knowledge (in pure form)

**Evidence**:
- **Feature Detectors**: Hubel and Wiesel discovered neurons in visual cortex that respond to specific features (edges, orientations, motion directions). More complex features are built from simpler ones.
- **Pop-Out Effect**: Distinctive features (a red item among green items) are detected rapidly and automatically, regardless of the number of distractors.
- **Texture Segmentation**: Regions with different textures are rapidly segregated without attention.
**Top-Down Processing (Concept-Driven Processing)**:
Top-down processing uses prior knowledge, expectations, context, and goals to guide perception.

**Characteristics**:
- Influenced by expectations and knowledge
- Context shapes interpretation
- Can be slow and effortful (though often automatic)
- May lead to errors (seeing what we expect)
**Evidence**:

**Context Effects**:
- **Word Superiority Effect**: Letters are recognized faster when part of a word than when presented alone.
- **Object Superiority Effect**: Features are recognized faster when part of coherent objects.
- **Scene Context**: Objects are recognized faster when they are contextually appropriate (e.g., a loaf of bread in a kitchen vs. in a bathroom).

**Expectations and Knowledge**:
- **Perceptual Set**: Readiness to perceive in a particular way. Previous experience or instructions bias perception.
- **Schema-Driven Processing**: Knowledge structures guide interpretation of ambiguous stimuli.
- **Reading Errors**: We often fail to notice typos because we see what we expect.
**Predictive Coding**:
A influential modern framework proposes that the brain continuously generates predictions about incoming sensory input, and perception reflects the brain's best guess about the world.

**Key Ideas**:
- Brain generates predictions based on prior experience and context
- Predictions are compared against actual sensory input
- Mismatches (prediction errors) drive learning and updating
- Perception reflects the brain's hypothesis about causes of sensory input

**Implications**:
- Explains top-down effects as predictions shaping perception
- Explains attention as precision-weighting of prediction errors
- May explain hallucinations as predictions unconstrained by sensory input
**Interaction of Bottom-Up and Top-Down Processing**:
Perception is neither purely bottom-up nor purely top-down but involves continuous interaction.
**Examples**:
**Reading Handwriting**: Bottom-up information about letter shapes combines with top-down knowledge of words and context to decipher ambiguous handwriting.
**Speech Perception**: Bottom-up acoustic information combines with top-down linguistic knowledge (phonotactic rules, word knowledge, sentence context) to perceive speech, especially in noise.
**Face Recognition**: Bottom-up processing of features combines with top-down knowledge of familiar faces and contextual expectations.
**Cocktail Party Effect**: Bottom-up distinctive features (e.g., your name) capture attention, which then enables top-down processing of that conversation.
**Clinical Implications**:

- **Hallucinations**: May reflect overweighting of top-down predictions relative to sensory input
- **Agnosia**: May reflect impaired integration of bottom-up information
- **Autism**: May involve reduced influence of top-down priors

fullSections.title: Attention and Perception
content: Attention is the cognitive process of selectively concentrating on relevant stimuli while ignoring irrelevant information. Attention and perception are intimately linked—what we perceive depends heavily on what we attend to.
**Types of Attention**:
**Selective Attention**: Focusing on one source of information while filtering out others.
**Divided Attention**: Distributing attention across multiple tasks or stimuli.
**Sustained Attention (Vigilance)**: Maintaining focus over extended periods.
**Spatial Attention**: Directing attention to locations in space.
**Feature-Based Attention**: Attending to specific features (e.g., all red objects).
**Object-Based Attention**: Attending to objects rather than locations or features.
**Theories of Selective Attention**:

**Early Selection (Broadbent's Filter Theory, 1958)**:
- Attention acts as a filter early in processing
- Selection based on physical features (location, pitch, color)
- Unattended information filtered out before meaning analyzed
- Explains why we can't report content of unattended message in dichotic listening

**Late Selection (Deutsch & Deutsch, 1963; Norman, 1968)**:
- All information is processed to the level of meaning
- Selection occurs after semantic analysis
- Explains breakthrough of meaningful information (e.g., own name) in unattended channel

**Attenuation Theory (Treisman, 1964)**:
- Compromise between early and late selection
- Unattended information is not filtered completely but attenuated (weakened)
- Meaningful information (e.g., own name) has low threshold and can break through even when attenuated
**Modern View**: Attention is flexible; the locus of selection depends on task demands and perceptual load.
**Failures of Attention**:
**Inattentional Blindness**: Failure to notice unexpected but fully visible objects or events when attention is focused elsewhere.
**Classic Demonstration**: Simons and Chabris (1999) gorilla study. Participants counting basketball passes often fail to notice a person in a gorilla suit walking through the scene.
**Implications**: Looking is not the same as seeing. Perception requires attention.
**Change Blindness**: Failure to detect changes in scenes when the change coincides with a brief visual disruption (eye movement, blink, flicker, occlusion).

**Demonstrations**:
- Flicker paradigm: Alternating between original and changed image with brief blank
- Change during eye movements
- 'Door' study: Person asking directions replaced during interruption
**Implications**: We do not maintain detailed representations of scenes; attention is required to encode specific features.

**Attentional Blink**: Reduced ability to detect a second target appearing 200-500 ms after the first target in rapid serial visual presentation (RSVP). Processing the first target depletes attentional resources.
**Visual Search**:
**Feature Search**: Target defined by single feature (e.g., red among green). Fast, parallel, independent of display size. Targets 'pop out.'

**Conjunction Search**: Target defined by combination of features (e.g., red horizontal among red verticals and green horizontals). Slow, serial, increases with display size. Requires attention to bind features.
**Feature Integration Theory (Treisman)**:
Explains why conjunction search is harder than feature search.

**Key Claims**:
- Basic features (color, orientation, size, motion) are registered automatically and in parallel across the visual field
- Focused attention is required to bind features together into unified object representations
- Without attention, features may be incorrectly combined (illusory conjunctions)
**Evidence for Illusory Conjunctions**: When attention is diverted, participants may report seeing a red O when shown a red X and a blue O. Features are 'free-floating' until bound by attention.
**The Binding Problem**:
How does the brain integrate information processed in different areas into unified conscious experience?

**Aspects of the Binding Problem**:
- Different features (color, motion, shape) processed in different brain areas
- Yet we perceive unified objects with all features combined
- How are the correct features bound together?

**Proposed Solutions**:
- **Temporal Synchrony**: Features of the same object represented by neurons firing in synchrony (gamma-band oscillations)
- **Attention**: Focused attention binds features (Feature Integration Theory)
- **Recurrent Processing**: Feedback connections integrate information across areas
**Neural Correlates of Attention**:

**Attention Effects in Brain**:
- Enhanced neural responses to attended stimuli in sensory cortex
- Reduced responses to unattended stimuli
- Modulation even in early visual areas (V1)
- Frontoparietal networks control attention shifts

**Key Brain Areas**:
- **Frontal Eye Fields**: Control of eye movements and spatial attention
- **Posterior Parietal Cortex**: Spatial attention, priority maps
- **Pulvinar (Thalamus)**: Filtering of irrelevant information
- **Superior Colliculus**: Orienting to salient stimuli
